content.description: Follow the crack behind the tree on the left side of the slab. The crack itself is in a black streak of the granite and features moderate protection. The crack angles up and to the right, eventually ending below a roof at an anchor with two bolts.
content.protection:
Decent but not great placements for nuts and cams up to 2". This shares a bolted anchor with the sport route,

Boot Camp

, to the right.

Per

Aidan Ireton

: this has been retrobolted.

Per

Joe K

: there are no bolts as of 4/5/20.
content.location: It is on the left side of Army Slab and starts on a ledge behind a large tree.

content.description: This is the furthest bolted line to the left on the Army Slab. Face climb on decent granite past four bolts to a bolted anchor.
content.location: It is on the left side of the slab to the left of the black streak and the big tree. There is a large ledge from which to belay.

content.description:
This is the toprope route to the right of

Ice Cream Crack

on the face.
content.protection: Two bolt anchor at the top.
content.location:
It is the second route from the right, on the face to the right of

Ice Cream Crack

.

content.description:
This route follows the most obvious crack system when on the right side of the slab. While not particularly long or sustained, it takes gear quite well, is fairly clean, and makes for a nice climb, especially for newer trad leaders.

It might be a little run out at the top, but the climbing for the last 20 feet is quite easy, so it isn't a big deal.
content.protection: Smaller to medium cams, nuts, and an old wiggly piton. There is a two bolt anchor at the top. Rope drag isn't a big issue.
content.location: This is the second route from the right of Army Slab.

content.description:
This route follows the black streak just to the left of

Ice Cream Crack

. It isn't terribly sustained, with only a couple of 5.9/5.10 moves, with the rest being 5.2 climbing.

That said, it shares anchors with

Ice Cream Crack

, so if you have the top rope set up anyway, you may as well give it a shot.
content.protection:
Small to medium cams, and stoppers. There isn't much for protection at the top but the climbing is pretty easy, just be careful. This shares a two bolt anchor with

Ice Cream Crack

.
content.location:
This is the fourth route from the right and starts just to the right of a large boulder with a short chimney behind it. It follows the black streak to the left of

Ice Cream Crack

.

content.description:
This is a different route than the 5.3 face climb listed in Bob and Carrie Robertson's guide to the area.

Starting just left of the tree on the ledge, climb up to a left-facing arete that eventually contours into a roof. Traverse 20 or 30 feet left under the roof to the anchor for

Ice Cream Crack

.

There most definitely is some choss on the climb, but we tried to clean it up as much as we could, but still be wary of loose rock. It has a nice alpine feel to me for some reason, probably because of the lichen and loose rock encountered, but the climbing is fun enough to make it worth doing at least once.
content.protection:
Cams up to 2.5". I didn't see many opportunities for nuts or other passive pro (although you could probably use some tricams if you want). Traverse left to the two bolt anchors for

Ice Cream Crack

.

This used just about an entire 60m rope, so you might want to avoid this if you have a shorter rope.
content.location: This is the rightmost route on the Army Slabs. Start to the left of the tree growing out of the ledge.

content.description:
Cruiser Gully is a fun scramble with a couple of 'moves' to the top of Army Slab you can lap if you get antsy waiting on others in your party to finish climbing.

Climb the easy corner/gully up to a short and easy dihedral up left near the top.

Walk off to the southeast, and scramble and traverse down easy slabs back to the belay area. The way back down is almost equally fun.
content.protection: This is best done as a scramble. I didn't see much in the way of gear placement opportunities.
content.location:
This is the obvious, easy gully/corner to the right of the tree which is about 20' right of

Ice Cream Crack

.

content.description: Boot Camp is a short, quick sport route on pretty good (for the area) granite. Face climb past four bolts to a bolted anchor below a roof.
content.protection: Four bolts to a bolted anchor.
content.location:
This is on a ledge sort of in the middle of Army Slab. The easiest approach is to go left to the ledge the large tree, and walk right past

Tree Crack

to a ledge a bit further up on top of a large boulder.
